head.title: Metro Business; Tenants Stage Rally On Rent Proposals

hedline.hl1: Metro Business; Tenants Stage Rally On Rent Proposals

block.p: Tenants' advocates protested proposed increases for tenants of rent stabilized apartments on the steps of City Hall yesterday, calling on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to sharply reduce the increases.

The protest came days before a preliminary vote on Monday by the city's Rent Guidelines Board on increases, proposed by landlords, of as much as 9 percent on one-year leases and 15 percent on two-year leases.
Tenants' advocates protested proposed increases for tenants of rent stabilized apartments on the steps of City Hall yesterday, calling on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to sharply reduce the increases.

The protest came days before a preliminary vote on Monday by the city's Rent Guidelines Board on increases, proposed by landlords, of as much as 9 percent on one-year leases and 15 percent on two-year leases.

Kenneth Schaeffer, the vice chairman of the tenants' group, the Metropolitan Council on Housing, said the proposals had been orchestrated by City Hall to make the mayor ''appear like a white knight'' who would use his influence to lower the rent increases somewhat, but to levels that he said would still unfairly burden low- and middle-income renters.
Mr. Giuliani, who appoints all nine members of the board, has called the proposed raises ''very, very high.''
